"Rise and shine, Mister Freeman. Rise and... shine. Not that I... wish to imply you have been sleeping on the job. No one is more deserving of a rest... and all the effort in the world would have gone to waste until... well, let's just say your hour has... come again.

The right man in the wrong place can make all the difference in the world. So, wake up, Mister Freeman. Wake up and... smell the ashes..."  Those words changed my vision of video games.

4/4

One of the all-time best FPS games balance-wise, and a fantastic continuation of the story foundation laid down by the first HL game. While the first game in the series contains themes about the overreach of the marriage between military and science, the second game follows with themes of active resistance to the grand designs of those who might exploit one or the other for personal gain. Beautiful.

It's been 20 years since the events of Half-Life and its expansions. In that timespan, an interdimensional alien empire known as the Combine came to Earth, conquered it in an event known as the Seven Hour War, and really did a number on both the planet and the human race during its occupation. The G-Man places Gordon Freeman onto a train bound for City 17, a Combine City  established in an undisclosed part of Eastern Europe, under the idea that "The right man in the wrong place can make all the difference in the world." Indeed, Gordon comes across the Resistance trying to fight the Combine, which happens to include Barney from Blue Shift, quite a few former Black Mesa scientists, and the daughter of one of those said scientists, Eli Vance (more-or-less the leader this Resistance), named Alyx, and ultimately helps them combat the alien occupiers.

If the first game was an absolute gem, then this game is genuinely one of the best FPSes of all time. Great set-pieces, excellent combat, pretty great physics for a 2004 game, a well-placed narrative, pretty good graphics for a game from the 2000's, great enemies to fight, and a very great soundtrack. This game truly has it all to be an excellent title.

Being a rather groundbreaking game, its legacy cannot be overstated, and it is a game I highly recommend experiencing.
